child.pub-comments: Some other names sometimes listed with Panoan languages are: Panavarro, Purus, Arazaire, Cujareño (Peru), Mayo (Maia, Maya, Pisabo, Pisagua) (Brazil, Peru), Nukuini (Nuquini [with dialect Cuyanawa]) (Brazil), and Uru-eu (Brazil) (Adelaar 2004:419, Shell 1975:14, Migliazza and Campbell 1988:189-90, Rodrigues 1986:77-81). Ethnologue has Sharanahua (Acre, Arara) as a distinct language (with dialects: Arinahua [Marináwa] and Chandinahua.
Campbell calls this the main branch.
Campbell calls this a language area.
Kaufman calls this an 'emergent language', which signifies that it is not quite distinct from other languages in the language area.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. The classification of South American languages. In Lyle Campbell & Verónica Grondona (eds.), South America. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. , Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 70-71. London, New York: Routledge.

child.pub-comments: "This language may be a mixture of various refugee Panoan languages." (Kaufman, pg.71) Speakers: 2000 Ethnologue lists Matse and Matis as two separate languages, but Campbell lists them as one.

child.pub-comments: Others also list Chirigua (from the mission of San Buenaventura, El Beni Department, Bolivia) as a Tacanan language. (Girard 1971a:41-2

"The names Ese'eha and Chama are not very satisfactory. Chama is a regional pejorative name for these indigenes. Comparative work has been done in Takanan: Girard (1971a) reconstructs proto-Takanan phonology using data from three languages: Takana, Kavinenyo, and Ese'eha - and supplementary data from two others. There are 504 cognate sets with reconstructions." (71)

child.alt-names: Ese'eha, Ese Ejja, Ese Exa, Tiatinagua, Chama, Tambopata-Guarayo, Huarayo, Guacanawa, Chuncho, “Chama"
